I actually like the game, but it is far from finished and still needs a lot of work. At the moment, there is only one part of the first chapter in the campaign, as well as a challenge mode with 3 maps, each with their own enemy layout. But if you are the hopeful or interested type that enjoys Resident Evil-like games (and sexy characters), you will maybe enjoy this one.

I would recommend it, but there is still many things to be desired. Below is a list of ideas, some more important than others of course. It should more serve as food for thought for the creator if he ever sees this review.

-A "Swap Shoulder" function to switch the camera position from the right shoulder to the left
-Better melee combat that doesn't rely on stunlocking the enemy
-Viable I-frames during dodging
-Prevention of player stunlock
-The fact that the character should swap to the weapon instead of empty hands after using an item
-Being able to move while healing even if slowly
-Removing that weird standing around and doing nothing at the end of the healing animation
-Being able to run more than just a few meters without being out of breath immediately
-Better placement of autosaves in the campaign (There is only one right at the start before any danger, thus eliminating most of the point of it other than being able to skip cutscenes)
-Possibly a mode that removes autosaves in favor of saving at savepoints manually, like Resident Evil
-Better enemy placement in the campaign (There is way too many for it to be scary, it just turns into a really bad shootout that requires you to have saved up ammo from the challenge modes)
-Actual riddles for the safes instead of having it written in the room somewhere, possibly having it written somewhere else for the player to find instead
-Being able to carry over the clothing you selected in your room into a campaign save you made already
-Having an "unlocked clothing" screen instead of just the clothes you have in your inventory
-Not having to save the clothing inside a box, there is currently no need for that because you will only ever change your clothes in front of a mirror that is in a safe room
-More reason to use the box other than to carry over items from one mode into the other
-More character sliders than just the waist and the breasts, and more options than just hair, hair color, clothing and general facial appearance
-More modes with possible permanent upgrades or unlocks to the character in them

And last and most importantly:
-Better communication with the playerbase

Some or all of these ideas are possibly already planned, but I have no way of knowing this without better communication with the playerbase. Unless that happens, communicating with the creator happens via these reviews... Unless of course you can read Chinese, I can't. I do hope that this review gets taken to heart, and I do hope that I can change the recommendation from No to Yes at some point. But that's where we are right now.

[h1]Wellington's [url=store.steampowered.com/app/1874220/GO/]GO[/url] mixes elements of brick breaker and pool in a relaxing minimalist package but lacks thoughtful strategic design.[/h1]

Break the whites and bounce off on blacks. Some pieces move, most are static.

With a mirror effect on screen edges, most of the 100 puzzles are either easy one-shot solves or fall into the trial-and-error category. You can let some levels run for 2 whole minutes and just watch the ball bounce off randomly until it clears all the pieces. Coupled with the occasional glitch, this makes solving puzzles rather unsatisfying.

For the tougher levels, I would have liked to see my last move's position before attempting another correction.

Go presumably took strong inspiration from Kamibox Games' more polished [i]Okay?[/i]. Okay is more musical and has more diverse elements (such as strings that make sounds but don't disappear). Go relies on screen mirroring to solve its puzzles while Okay does not. Yet the similarities are otherwise striking beyond coincidence, both in terms of concept and presentation.

[h1]Positive[/h1]
[list]
[*] Nice minimalist aesthetic
[*] Relaxing
[*] Very affordable
[/list]

[h1]Negative[/h1]
[list]
[*] Puzzles can get solved by accident with the ball going off-screen without limits in ways that were clearly not intended
[*] No options to reset progress or replay previous puzzles
[*] Ball occasionally passes through solid blocks
[*] Derivative of another indie title without improving the formula
[/list]

It amazes me to think how many people truly believe that they understand the meaning of pain. They wail about petty grievances and trifling discomforts while swaddled in their Miffy the Rabbit blankets, thinking themselves worthy of commiseration. 'I have pancreatic cancer,' they cry; 'my dad makes me call him "Honeypuff"', they lament. 

I curse these squalling babes. Every last one of them is irredeemable, save by the act of crawling in shame back into their mother's womb and cannibalising the slattern from within, as punishment for ever daring to bring them into a world not made for their kind.

My anguish, conversely, spans decades, and runs through my blood from the uttermost depths of my being. I have sworn fealty to the realm of Dransik since the beginning. Twenty years I served, languishing beneath swarms of bats and the molestations of giant spiders in search of higher purpose. Never before had pixels so bestirred my heart. Here were forged the most enduring and meaninful friendships of my life. And even in this unforgiving land of magma and impenetrable woodland teeming with carnivorous squirrels, betimes love did blossom, and my paramours and I gambolled about the meadows, petting sheep and smelling what were, if one squinted, most likely flowers. 

A life without Dransik was not one I could bear to contemplate. Alas, entropy is but one of many symptoms of the disease we name life, and sooner or later, the greatest of humanity's works all fall prey to rot. What exists on Steam today is merely a shadow of Dransik's former splendour. Gone are the early morning 200 player orgies, gone are the seal parades, gone is the thriving economy fuelled by the slave labour of hapless new players. It is a husk, a barren shell, an ensemble of bones dancing on puppet strings held by the careless and incompetent. 

Abandon all hope ye who enter here. Dransik is dead. Joy is dead. And soon I shall follow suit.

And it avoids massive boring camping in games that are sorta Battle Royales like Hunt Showdown and Tarkov.

The fact you can learn the controls, learn the routes, and find little ways to cut time off a trip was so genuinely fun to do between gunfights for me. It became more fun than the gun play for a good amount of my playtime.

Match vs Menu times are probably the best of any Battle Royale .There is something absolutely amazing about this games queue taking seconds, followed by the game itself being ready to start in seconds.  Even when you lose, it doesn't feel like a big deal because a game could start again in literally 10 seconds. Not find a match in 10 seconds, or load. I mean START.

This game has potential. It definitely isn't there yet, but hopefully the dev continues to improve things. It's a fun, casual tower defense game at its core, but there's just not enough to truly recommend it. Gameplay is too linear, lacks complexity, and becomes repetitive in the late game. You build enough lightning towers and star towers with archers as DPS, then you go into maintenance mode to make sure you have enough mana. I would like to see more variety in towers, alternate tower abilities, tier levels, and more upgrades. The research early game is too slow and if you miss out on crucial cards (Library, Pylon, Furnace, Swamp...) then you'll have to wait forever for them to reappear via RNG. These required cards shouldn't be part of the draw. It hinders gameplay, creating a bad experience. It's not a challenge.

Then there are some minor issues. The star and lightning towers are too powerful. The radius of the speed tower and the towers it affects isn't clear. It should highlight the towers that are within the radius. And the game should go on longer than 50 levels. I had no trouble on Medium difficulty to beat the game on my second try. I might go for a third game on Hard difficulty, but I don't feel motivated to do so due to the lack of variety in gameplay. Maybe the dev is mistaking RNG for gameplay variety and challenge. I don't know.

Anyway, it's a decent game. I'd like to see some improvements fleshing things out and balancing the game overall. I'll come back around for updates.

This game is very much a mixed bag for me. Many of my issues are personal preferences and gripes, however this is my review, so I will list those here. This monster of a review will be split into multiple parts, so for the dumbed down version, scroll to the bottom, although for more specifics, I definitely recommend reading the whole thing.

*Graphics/Performance:* Now, this game is styled to look like something out of an early PS1 game, meaning the graphics by todays standards are not greatest, however, that is the style the game is going for, so I have no complaints there. My complaints are with the game's performance. For a game with such low poly textures and models (At least from what is visible through all the screen effects), trying to run this game on a Mac like me, on any setting higher than "Low" is unbearable. The game stutters like crazy and just runs really slow unless you're on a low setting and even then, it still still has fps drops. (For reference, I can run games like "The Forest" just fine with little to no FPS drops ever). The original Lancaster leak had this same problem, but it was a lot worse, so there seems to have been an effort to fix this. Either way, I give the graphics a good 7/10, and the performance a 4/10.

*Controls:* This game has tank controls, which for a lot of people could be an immediate turn off. For me tank controls are a little annoying but I can bear them. The problem with this however, is the fact that if you are walking towards the camera, your controls will inverse, so instead of turning right you will turn left for example. It's not a huge thing but gets really annoying at times. Overall I give the controls a 5/10

*Gameplay:* Another little gripe I have with this game is the gameplay. This game is comprised of multiple fetch quests. However the original Lancaster Leak was a glorified walking simulator so either way this is an improvement. But in the original I could excuse the lack of any real gameplay because of how excellently done the horror element was, but in this game, the horror element is kind of lackluster. I did not once find the entity scary, as there was never a moment in the game where it could actually kill you if it you were chased, and it only ever showed up during scripted sequences, making it seem much less scary. I would have loved if there was a portion of the game where the entity was wandering around, and you had to hide in lockers or something whenever it walked by, however that would require a much larger map, so it probably would not have worked. I give the gameplay a 7/10. It was fun for the first 10 or so minutes, but then it got very repetitive.

*Lore/Story:* This is the game's saving grace. The lore is very intriguing and the entity description and how the story was presented is absolutely perfect. On top of that the voice acting is absolutely incredible, it is seriously impressive the emotion that the character managed to convey in the very few lines they had. I give this section a 10/10

*Conclusion:* Overall, this game is a 6.6/10. The graphics fit the theme of the game, however the performance is absolutely atrocious at times, which takes away from it, the controls are annoying and janky, and the gameplay is very mediocre (However it is still an improvement over the gameplay from the last one). This game is absolutely saved by it's very well presented story. While it does have it's problems, it's only worth it due to the fact that it is free. If this even cost a dollar, I would say its not worth the money, dont buy it, but like I said it's free. So yeah, 6.6/10.

-During the first appearance of the entity, the character does not look at it when it plays the weird frightened animations, which takes away from the immersion.

-During the ending cutscene, where the entity kills everybody in the call center, you can see both the hands of the entity and the hands of the body clipping through the exit door in the alley camera angle.

-You can grab the meeting room trash through the wall.

-There are multiple typo's throughout the many text sections of the game.

This game is really fun, but as many others are saying, the time crunch aspect of the game really weighs down on all other points. It's a nonstop scramble to find resources, upkeep potions, talk with characters, attempt to make the potions again, and repeat. It's got an insane potential to be really fun *IF* there was a more lenient time scheme. I can see how players would improve a lot between each replay, but the time it takes to rebuild your business is monotonous in comparison to how fast the gameplay is, leading to a lot of waiting when you're redoing a previous save, and stress when it suddenly gets harder.

I consider myself fairly okay at these sorts of things, and okay with multitasking, but even still at the 2nd competition I was roadblocked because I didn't manage to get the right ingredients. 
The major issues that could be adjusted to allow for less skilled players to enjoy the game:
-A difficulty slider to expand the time between challenges so you don't feel overwhelmed every waking moment, OR more actions in a day. Honestly this would be just as fun if not more if the deadlines were monthly, giving a LOT of chill time to practice and build progress like Stardew Valley
-Easier opponents/more cards in a deck/less aggressive stress system. Early on, the game is a breeze, with the first challenge being a minor problem. However everything dominoes if you can't make a proper potion for the event (which also is judged in a specific order, so if your last potion is the best, it might not go that long). Once you don't have a potion that surpasses the best expectations, it just becomes a Sisyphean struggle to maybe win the challenge with your haggling skills.
-Recipe saving. Similar to a different game on steam called 'Potion Craft', this game has you toss ingredients into a cauldron and you have to mix and match them based on what attributes they have. It's... not too bad, but it can get confusing when you're managing the main 3 potions for each round and you're constantly out of one ingredient or so. It would be IDEAL if you could save successful ingredient combinations to potion recipes so it automatically puts it together for you, saving time dramatically.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Played on a i7-8700, 16GB RAM, GTX1070Ti with a Valve Index (90Hz refresh rate, Motion Smoothing on). Observations are as follow:

- For VR users, the controls would benefit from being able to do one of the following: (i) Have traditional flight controls as an option (e.g. pitch, strafe, roll, thrust assigned to the joysticks).  The ability to do rolls alongside pitch/strafe while in these worlds would enhance the immersiveness of being withIN this world, whereas right now I feel I am moving strictly along a x-y plane with 'thrust' simulating the z-axis. (ii) Allow an option for where head movements are independent of the motion controllers.  Being able to look around, while controlling my direction/orientation with the controllers gives myself a better feel of immersion.
I guess when it comes to flying around, either I'm doing it inside of a cockpit, or I should be doing doing Superman-style (Literally have your hands out in front of you, and the movement of your arms controls like a plane (except for speed).

- The 3D effects in VR feel more like overlays on top of one another, more than eveything feeling as part of the same world.  If anybody has tried playing a 2D first-person game game with VorpX (a 3-D infuser type program used to simulate VR within your headset, to varying degrees of success), you'll know better of what I am trying to relate.

The 3D effects in VR are by no means horrible, but as other reviewers have mentioned, it feels a bit 'off' .

- The 'black-n-white-n-grey' levels have more artificating going on in the level compared to the color levels.  As a result, the non-color levels often have varying degrees of 'shimmering' going on wehn viewing objects at  a distance, often to the point where it is distracting and makes me think of a Playstation 1 game in extreme cases.  Conversely, getting closer to objects just about always enhances their detail.
The color levels have their share of artificating, but the 'blending' of colors offers a more subdued contrast, and eliminates a fair portion of any shimmering that might be there.

- The most amazing part of this experience is the discovery of 'worlds within worlds' when flying through the levels.  Just flying along on top of the 'Death Star' level was initially disappointing, but go underneath the surface, and dive deeper into the structures themselves, and I have discovered far more intersting levels to explore.

- The music is relaxing, but a mix-up of themes would be welcome.  I'm not saying the 'black-n-white-n-grey' need Star Wars music, but something more 'operatic' might enhance the immersiveness for myself.

This game is not fun to play, I applaud the developers for making an actually quality game, there is no broken UI or something that makes it unplayable. It even has control remapping, which is better than most AAA games! However, a puzzle game is only as good as its puzzles, and this game is just not it. If you expect any mechanic to be explained to you, then good luck. Most puzzles have you wondering what you are even trying to do only for you to solve it by accident. The first "puzzle" you play is a memory game similar to a Simon Says but with more buttons, however, if you mess up on the last one like I did, the game doesn't reset you to the start to try again like it should, no, it just rearranges the order. On the max difficulty. Good luck trying to memorize a sequence you've never seen before while it flashes 7 different buttons. Two puzzles I had a hard time with were the "Watch your step!" puzzle and the "Chosen One" puzzle. The former puzzle, as you can guess, I solve on accident after 20 minutes of trying to piece together "maybe the order or the colors on the flipped hue axis or maybe it has something to do with the colors that don't show up on the first row or-" It was instead just only step on the colors that weren't glowing, the problem being the room is well lit so it makes it hard to tell what is glowing or not, and the maze switches to a new layout every time you die. The latter puzzle is coincidentally the last puzzle in the game, where you put 5 colors in the right order. This took me over an hour of randomly guessing, going through each possible combination and throwing pieces of scratch paper to find the solution. The way you are supposed to find the solution is the 5 pillars in front of you that increase in height, allowing you to parkour to the final door. The last pillar however is hidden until you beat the puzzle, and the order has nothing to do with their hue, the number of sides on the shape, the height of the pillar, or the height of the actual buttons themselves. All of those are red herrings, and I still don't know why they made all the buttons different heights, but you are supposed to put in the visual order that they appear in while viewing them from the pedestal where the puzzle is. And guess on the green one's order because it's hidden until the puzzle that it's required for is solved; like a key in its own lockbox. What would have made it better is if there was different songs for each puzzles, but there is only really 2 main songs you hear play, and loop, until you guess the right combination. It got to the point where I had to mute the music because how often it looped. Pair this with janky cut-scene animations and illexistant story and you get a kind of meh experience. I doubt this game will appear on anyone's must play list, or it will get extraordinarily popular, but the game never did anything wrong or outright unplayable. It's just that the puzzles suck.

TRANSFER CHARACTERS FROM DARK SUNS SHATTERED LANDS TO WAKE OF THE RAVAGER!!! First, you need to beat Shattered Lands, then when it drops you back into the game do any remaining side quests you want to and then save it. For steam you have to edit the game.conf in the Dark Sun 2 folder. Take the save game file from the original game, create a folder in the Dark Suns 2 Dosbox game folder where the RAVAGER folder is and name the new folder DSUN. At this point the only two folders should be RAVAGER and DSUN. this is the folder that Dosbox uses for C:\. Place the save game file from Dark Sun Shattered lands into the DSUN folder you just created. Now find the game.conf in the Dark Suns 2 folder  and edit it with notepad. Change where it says RAVAGE.BAT to CHARTRAN.EXE and save. Run the game like normal, it should show up with a screen that says something like C:\dsun C:\Ravager press enter to transfer. Press enter, you'll see it throw the character names up there and its done. Change the line in game.conf from CHARTRAN.EXE back to RAVAGE.BAT save and they should show up when you go to character creation, right click and chose add. You'll get the vast majority of your items when you start a game in ravager. All xp past lvl 9 will be added and after the first combat event you'll level up to where you XP is. For example my mage leveled from 9 to 12 immediately because even though the level cap in the first game was 9 I had the XP to get to lvl 12. Some of the armor pieces and various books and quest items turned into 1 ceramic piece and one belt turned into a leather body armor. I wish I new about this feature back in the 90's I probably would have given this game more a chance.

[h1]In-Depth[/h1]

With Good Intentions spans across two separate timelines. The present one is set in a 1800s-esque environment that sees captain Paul Lange lead his imperial scouts, alongside numerous allies through the countryside, after a major rebellion toppled the government and put the military in disarray. In the past one, you’ll instead play as Rayon Von Eigo, master of his own knightly order and charged with commanding the Shemergard fortress, in place to repel enemy invasions.

Most of the story, in both timelines, takes place in this massive fortress-monastery and its environs. There’s a stark contrast between the past and present versions of the place, with the former being well-maintained and stocked, while the one visited by Lange in the future is not only dilapidated, but seemingly haunted by dark forces as well. What once was a mighty fortress now lies in ruins, becoming a last ditch attempt to shelter a routing army.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2891765465

The atmosphere is quite excellent, even if the lack of music and sound effects in most ordinary scenes takes away some of the pathos. The different art styles applied to respectively talks, action scenes and narration panels come together nicely and offer some aesthetic variation that is indeed, welcome. With Good Intentions saves most of its soundtrack and SFX for the most important scenes - with a probably limited budget, this is a wise choice indeed.

Main and side characters are of inconsistent make: some quirky and intriguing individuals may arise from time to time, however it’s also true some of the (supposedly) centerpieces of the adventure just prove bland and one-sided (such as Lange’s sidekick sergeant, to name one). There’s a lack of insight in most characters’ personal life or ideas, as there simply won’t be the chance to have any dialogue with them that isn’t related to the main story’s progress. This becomes especially true and evident in later chapters and will be a hindrance if you’re trying to understand anything beyond the characters’ role in the fortress environment. There’s never any further elaboration on the world or lore either, making the monastery seem like a self-contained bubble (and in some ways, it actually is) where no topics except the daily misadventures ever exist. Sure, you’ll hear some rumors and trivia but that’s it.

With Good Intentions is made unique by its handling of death - because yes, in this visual novel you can actually die - as Von Eigo at least. Basically, every time you take a wrong ‘route’, your demise will be inevitable, be it at the hand of an enemy or more mysterious forces. The knowledge acquired from dialogues and actions will however be kept for the next instance of what essentially is a time loop, with Rayon being able to use it to change things to his favor. Each ‘past’ sequence is ultimately a combination puzzle where you die until you find the right set of actions that give a (single) good ending, thus finishing the chapter. In the present, conversely, you won’t be able to die, no matter how badly you may seem to screw up.

On paper this system would be intriguing, but it’s terribly implemented for the most part. Technical shenanigans aside (and those are already enough because let’s be honest, it’s a visual novel, not Space Engineers) there is a clear lack of proofreading and mediocre translation quality; expect weird syntax and wording as common issues. On top of that, the absence of manual saving and the inability to skip to the next choice immediately, when repeating an already-seen dialogue, make the experience tedious because the non-adjustable text speed is too low (even with speed-up enabled). This leads to an enormous amount of wasted time and filler that have no place in any decent visual novel.

Another huge flaw is found in the numerous non-sequiturs (in layman terms: nonsense) related to the causes of death, or to the available choices in some dialogues. On numerous occasions you’ll find poor Rayon dying for arbitrary reasons that at times are not even explained properly, or him suddenly unable to use critical information in a logical way, simply because that choice wasn’t accounted for. It leaves a bitter, disappointing taste to see how much potential was wasted due to mediocre writing and dubious logic.

Exoprimal is a fun PvEvP experience right from the get-go. The suits are incredibly diverse with unique abilities and personalities, and being able to actively switch between the suits is a nice change in comparison to other hero shooters. Dinosaurs piling on-top of you in droves, with your typical variants of suicide bombers and snipers hunting you as-well. Missions seem to be randomly generated, with wave based, competitive speed-running-esque objectives to [spoiler]all 10 players forming a truce to fight a boss enemy, [/spoiler] ending in PVP Payload like missions to charging a hammer to slam a barrier away. The game play loop is fun enough that I feel like most players can enjoy it. However, everything else surrounding the game sounds like an absolute nightmare. Full AAA price game, with a battle pass, confirmed microtransactions and I can only assume DLC characters isn't exactly consumer friendly. The game at full AAA price isn't something a lot of people are willing to shell out already for a multiplayer exclusive title, especially for a brand new IP from a company with a history of failures for multiplayer games. Although I think the game is [i]fun[/i], I don't see how it's going to stand up on two feet without some serious changes to the monetization and price of the game. It's going to be a game that people are going to play for a week on Xbox Game Pass and forget, while Capcom declares it a failure and shelves it. I actively encourage everyone to share your opinions on the [url=https://event2.capcom.com/exoprimal-obt/surveylang]survey[/url] in hopes that they listen to players a bit.

Snips & Snails is an otome game centered around a college student (nameable by the player, default Lacy) in a contemporary/urban fantasy world where supernatural beings—known as "Arcane" or "Arcs"—have recently become officially known to humans and now freely intermingle after a long period of secrecy. Most of that background doesn't affect the MC much, though, with the story largely centered around her interactions with the Alatars, a family of Arcs whose sons (mage Sullivan, vampire Quinn, and incubus Yuuto) all happen to attend the same college she does. (There's also a fourth LI, Eryck, the ghost who "haunts" the Alatar residence.) Major side characters include the MC's dad and her best friend Arabella, the latter of whom also grows closer to one of the boys.

The story is fairly straightforward romance, with the MC getting closer to the guy of your choice, plus a subplot involving mysterious dreams that the MC starts having. Each route has a good ending and a neutral/bad ending, as well an unlockable epilogue and bonus story. There are also optional text-only sex scenes (no explicit images, text roughly as explicit as the average print romance novel).

So, let's start off with the good things:

- The art is nice, especially the CG art.

- There are interesting things about the setting and worldbuilding. Even though generally Snips & Snails trends much more heavily towards slice of life than fantasy, for the most part I don't really feel like the fantasy elements have been wasted (which tends to be an issue with fantasy slice of life).

- The sex scenes are optional, with no game penalty for choosing not to read through them.

- There are a couple other not-story-affecting choices that I appreciated having (whether or not MC is a virgin, whether or not she drinks alcohol) just for story flavor purposes.

- [spoiler]Thanks for making the cute vampire bi, even if it only comes up at the end of a route that's not his, and his boyfriend's identity kind of makes the plot of a third route fall apart if you think about it[/spoiler]

Unfortunately...

- The writing just isn't very good. It reads like someone's first attempt at writing a story—and if it were just that it would be a commendable attempt. But this is a commercial game; you have to pay money to play it.

- The script does not appear to have been edited or proofread in any way; besides the fact that there's nobody listed as an editor or proofreader in the credits, there are frequent typos and places where characters say things that sound extremely unnatural or awkward (where it doesn't make sense for them to seem unnatural/awkward). When the writing is the primary focus of the game, it [b]needs to be treated as such[/b], not as an afterthought like this feels.

- The sex scenes in particular are extremely awkward—not just in writing, but also in staging. Because there are no CGs there, instead you get to see the LI's half-naked sprite do absolutely nothing through the whole scene (where the text makes it clear that he's very much not doing absolutely nothing). A black screen as the background would genuinely be preferable; just having the bedroom background with no sprites would work too.

- The game itself feels stiff. Sprites rarely move when it seems like they should, keeping the same expression for long periods of time. There are conversations that go on and on with none of the characters on screen moving in any way. I'm not asking for the developer to go so far as to include animations or Live2D, those absolutely aren't necessary for a good VN, but just having the sprites regularly change expression and/or move across the screen can do a lot for engagement.

- The game's hero banner spoils every CG in the game (and by extension a major plot point). This is a relative nitpick, but if you're someone who doesn't like having CGs spoiled, it might be an annoyance.

In all, while there is some potential here, ultimately Snips & Snails falls flat in its most important area, and thus I can't recommend it. While the visual issues are inconsequential enough that I could overlook them in a better-written game, the script would need a massive overhaul or total rewrite in order to get to a level that I could recommend spending money on it. With all that said, there [i]is[/i] enough potential here that, with practice and editing, I could definitely see this developer release a quality VN in the future!

The aforementioned character design and sway, the card game that actually eventually gets fun, the detailed map you can travel that makes it seem like a real world that could be its own full open-world experience if they wanted to make it such, and the sense of progression. Leveling up is appealing, and once you actually figure out what the stats each *do*, it's rewarding and satisfying... eventually. And in combat, it's actually a bit rewarding to see the women get more and more naked, and more and more of their beautiful, sexy bodies become exposed, as you whittle their health down - even if it's annoying that the dialogue afterward never once acknowledges that this is what's happening and the cutscene that follows (unless you're just going straight for the sex scene) has them fully reclothed like nothing happened.

I personally like the portrayal of a vast open-world experience through the use of menus and textboxes, and it delivers here. To say nothing of that these quests are the few moments in the game where the protagonist actually seems like a good guy, or at least he can be if you have the right stats or make the right choices.

The nail in the coffin is that the devs only seem to respond to comments in the discussions in Cyrillic. Us English speakers tend to get ignored, left out of what would otherwise be a saving grace of community interaction. Pretty much every issue I have here could be allayed if the devs had only written back to let me know they read my suggestions and are thinking about it.

I can't deny I'll probably pull this up again eventually, but I wouldn't buy Aura Hearts again if I had the chance to redo it, knowing what I know now.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.
